issues.description: Constructor parameter order for Meal is inconsistent between the problem specification/UML and the template. The UML and the solution use Meal(String name, String[] ingredients) (name first), but the template's Meal constructor is declared as Meal(String[] ingredients, String name) (ingredients first). This will confuse students and breaks the example usages in the provided (commented) Main which instantiate Meal with (name, ingredients).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template Meal constructor match the specification/UML and the solution: change the template constructor signature to public Meal(String name, String[] ingredients) and update parameter ordering in the implementation. Also ensure any example usages in Main or documentation match this order.

issues.description: The problem text instructs students to initialize both fields (orders and stock) in the SealSaloon constructor, but elsewhere explicitly requires the stock attribute to be static (and final/read-only). Initializing a static final field in an instance constructor contradicts Java rules/idioms and conflicts with the solution, which declares and initializes the static final stock at its declaration. This inconsistency could confuse students about where/how to declare and initialize the shared stock.
issues.suggested_fix: Clarify the problem statement: either (A) require the stock to be an instance (non-static) final field initialized in the constructor, or (B) require a static (final) stock and instruct students to initialize it at its declaration or in a static initializer. Prefer option B to match the tests/solution: state explicitly that stock should be declared static final and initialized at the point of declaration (or in a static initializer), while orders should be initialized in the instance constructor.

issues.description: The constructor signature for Meal is inconsistent between the problem/UML and the template code. The problem statement (UML) and the solution expect Meal(String name, String[] ingredients) but the template implements public Meal(String[] ingredients, String name) (parameters reversed). This mismatch makes it harder for students to map the UML/requirements to the provided code and can produce confusion or compile-time errors if example usages (e.g., in Main or tests) assume the (String, String[]) ordering.
issues.suggested_fix: Change the Meal constructor in the template to match the UML and solution: public Meal(String name, String[] ingredients) { this.name = name; this.ingredients = ingredients; }. Ensure any example usages (Main or tests) use the same parameter order.
